entry.title: 9 Lessons From 25 Years of Linux Kernel Development
entry.summary: Because the Linux kernel community celebrated a quarter-century of development in 2016, many people ...
entry.content: Because the Linux kernel community celebrated a quarter-century of development in 2016, many people have asked us the secret to the project's longevity and success. I usually laugh and joke that we really have no idea how we got here. The project has faced many disagreements and challenges along the way. But seriously, the reason we've made it this far has a lot to do with the community's capacity for introspection and change.

entry.title: Looking At GNU/Linux's Performance Over 2016 With Intel's Clear Linux
entry.summary: If you have been curious how the performance of the GNU/Linux stack has evolved over 2016, I ran som...
entry.content: If you have been curious how the performance of the GNU/Linux stack has evolved over 2016, I ran some benchmarks of the rolling-release Clear Linux from the start of 2016 compared to this week to see how gains in the upstream software have evolved as well as their aggressive out-of-the-box optimizations for this operating system out of Intel's Open-Source Technology Center.

entry.summary: Earlier today while waiting for the Linux 4.9 release, I ran some fresh gitstats on the latest Linux...
entry.content: Earlier today while waiting for the Linux 4.9 release, I ran some fresh gitstats on the latest Linux kernel Git tree to see the latest numbers on the kernel for those interested in some analytics...

entry.title: Google DeepMind Makes AI Training Platform Publicly Available
entry.summary: Alphabet Inc.’s artificial intelligence division Google DeepMind is making the maze-like game platfo...
entry.content: Alphabet Inc.’s artificial intelligence division Google DeepMind is making the maze-like game platform it uses for many of its experiments available to other researchers and the general public.

entry.title: RIT to develop hybrid biological cell separations technology for lab-on-chip devices
entry.summary: (Rochester Institute of Technology) Research being done at Rochester Institute of Technology to refi...
entry.content: (Rochester Institute of Technology) Research being done at Rochester Institute of Technology to refine lab-on-chip devices -- highly sophisticated laboratories on microchips -- will provide more detailed and timely information to detect diseases such as cancer.

entry.content: NVIDIA today unveiled the world's first artificial intelligence computer designed to drive fully autonomous robotaxis.

entry.title: Intel presents 17-qubit superconducting chip with advanced packaging
entry.summary: Today, Intel announced the delivery of a 17-qubit superconducting test chip for quantum computing to...
entry.content: Today, Intel announced the delivery of a 17-qubit superconducting test chip for quantum computing to QuTech, Intel's quantum research partner in the Netherlands. The new chip was fabricated by Intel and features a unique design to achieve improved yield and performance.

source.title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

entry.title: How the cone snail's deadly venom can help us build better medicines
entry.summary: (National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)) By researching deadly cone snail venom, NIST...
entry.content: (National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)) By researching deadly cone snail venom, NIST researchers hope to find solutions to tough medical problems and diseases.

source.title: EurekAlert! - Chemistry, Physics and Materials Sciences

entry.title: Growing human brain cells in the lab
entry.summary: A cost-effective technology has been developed to produce large quantities of human brain cells in t...
entry.content: A cost-effective technology has been developed to produce large quantities of human brain cells in two simple steps. By surmounting major challenges in human neuron-based drug discovery, researchers believe this technique will be adopted widely in both basic science and industry.

entry.title: Sequencing test enables precise identification of drug-resistant TB
entry.summary: Two studies document how a new advanced genetic sequencing approach can help thwart the growing worl...
entry.content: Two studies document how a new advanced genetic sequencing approach can help thwart the growing worldwide threat posed by drug-resistant mutations of tuberculosis (TB). The threat of TB is increasing in some places as mutant versions of the disease become more and more resistant to current drug treatments.

entry.title: Oxytocin and breastfeeding: Elucidation of a molecular mechanism
entry.summary: Oxytocin is indispensable for developing the social brain. Suckling babies absorb oxytocin from moth...
entry.content: Oxytocin is indispensable for developing the social brain. Suckling babies absorb oxytocin from mother's milk, but gut closure occurs soon after birth to prevent uptake of undesired and desired macromolecules. Researchers have found that the molecule RAGE, on the intestinal epithelium, transports oxytocin into the blood even after gut closure. This finding suggests the advantage of breastfeeding and oral oxytocin administration to increase its concentration in blood and mother-child bond.

entry.title: Major breakthrough identifies new mechanism for the development of schizophrenia
entry.summary: The new research shows that dysfunctional brain blood vessels may be associated with the development...
entry.content: The new research shows that dysfunctional brain blood vessels may be associated with the development of schizophrenia. There is potential for new treatments of schizophrenia by developing new drugs to target these abnormal blood vessels.

entry.title: UTA bioengineer to collaborate with UTSW to improve neonatal brain monitoring
entry.summary: (University of Texas at Arlington) A University of Texas at Arlington bioengineering professor and h...
entry.content: (University of Texas at Arlington) A University of Texas at Arlington bioengineering professor and her team will integrate a portable brain imaging system with an advanced signal-processing technique for newborns that will better measure the babies' neurophysiology in real time, providing physicians the analysis needed to treat encephalopathy or brain swelling more quickly.

source.title: EurekAlert! - Chemistry, Physics and Materials Sciences

entry.title: Pest resistance to biotech crops surging
entry.summary: (University of Arizona) Pest resistance to genetically engineered crops Bt crops is evolving faster ...
entry.content: (University of Arizona) Pest resistance to genetically engineered crops Bt crops is evolving faster now than before, UA researchers show in the most comprehensive study to date. But as expected from evolutionary theory, resistance can be delayed if farmers comply with recommendations to make use of abundant refuges.

entry.title: Evolution: The beneficiaries of mass extinction
entry.summary: (University of Birmingham) Mass extinctions were followed by periods of low diversity in which certa...
entry.content: (University of Birmingham) Mass extinctions were followed by periods of low diversity in which certain new species dominated wide regions of the supercontinent Pangaea, reports a new study.

entry.title: Fossil find pushes back date of earliest fused bones in birds by 40 million years
entry.summary: (Phys.org)—A trio of researchers with the Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins o...
entry.content: (Phys.org)—A trio of researchers with the Key Laboratory of Vertebrate Evolution and Human Origins of Chinese Academy of Sciences has found evidence that pushes back the earliest example of fused bones in birds by approximately 40 million years. In their paper published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, Min Wang, Zhiheng Li and Zhonghe Zhou describe their study of the fossilized remains of a bird dated to approximately 120 million years ago.

source.title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

entry.title: wattOS Energizes Aging Hardware
entry.summary: wattOS is a stunning example of really great things coming in small packages. wattOS is a li...
entry.content: wattOS is a stunning example of really great things coming in small packages. wattOS is a lightweight and fast desktop Linux distribution based on Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS built around the LXDE. It uses the lightweight Openbox window manager as its default user interface. To credit this 8-year-young community of developers with birthing an energy-efficient Linux distribution is an understatement. It has phenomenal performance on older hardware that lacks resources. It installs on computers with as little as 192 MB to 256 MB of RAM.

entry.title: US Government Opens Access to Federal Source Code with Code.gov
entry.summary: In March of this year, the Obama administration created a draft for Federal Source Code policy to su...
entry.content:
In March of this year, the Obama administration created a draft for Federal Source Code policy to support improved access to custom software code. After soliciting comments from public,  the administration announced the Federal Source Code policy in August.

One of the core features of the policy was the adoption of an open source development model:

entry.title: New IBM Platform Brings Watson to IoT
entry.summary: IBM unveiled today an experimental platform that allows developers to embed Watson functions and cog...
entry.content: IBM unveiled today an experimental platform that allows developers to embed Watson functions and cognitive technology into various devices. The platform, dubbed Project Intu, can be accessed through the Watson Developer Cloud, Intu Gateway, and GitHub.

entry.title: AWS Launches Linux Container Image for On-Premise
entry.summary: AWS has launched a new Linux Container Image in response to customer demand, designed for use with c...
entry.content:
AWS has launched a new Linux Container Image in response to customer demand, designed for use with cloud and on-premise workloads.

Linux AMI is a secure environment for firing up applications running on EC2, but due to customer demand, AWS has now made the image available for on-premise as well as cloud infrastructures, addressing more businesses' needs.

"Many of our customers have asked us to make this Linux image available for use on-premises, often as part of their development and testing workloads," Jeff Barr, chief evangelist for AWS, said.

entry.title: Understanding memory information on Linux systems
entry.summary: Understanding Linux memory information Every operating system needs memory to store program code seg...
entry.content:
Understanding Linux memory information Every operating system needs memory to store program code segments and data. This is also true for Linux systems. The problem: there is a lot of information available regarding memory usage and its behavior. Let’s discover how Linux manages its memory and how we can gather memory information. Great for troubleshooting, but also to learn more about the inner workings of our system. Random access memory When we talk about memory in this article, we usually mean [...]

The post Understanding memory information on Linux systems appeared first on Linux Audit.

entry.title: An Introduction to Linux Filesystems
entry.summary: This article is intended to be a very high-level discussion of Linux filesystem concepts. It is not ...
entry.content: This article is intended to be a very high-level discussion of Linux filesystem concepts. It is not intended to be a low-level description of how a particular filesystem type, such as EXT4, works, nor is it intended to be a tutorial of filesystem commands.

entry.title: Power Consumption & Efficiency Of The Linux Kernel For The Last Three Years
entry.summary: Earlier this week I published Linux 3.9 through Linux 4.9 kernel benchmarks looking at the raw perfo...
entry.content: Earlier this week I published Linux 3.9 through Linux 4.9 kernel benchmarks looking at the raw performance of various subsystems when testing each of the major kernel releases as far back as this Core i7 Haswell system was supported. From that same system, today is a look at testing the kernels going back to Linux 3.11 when Haswell graphics support was first in good shape for this Core i7 4790K box while looking at the raw power consumption and performance-per-Watt for these 19 major kernel releases.

entry.title: Open Source Operating Systems for IoT
entry.summary: Over the past decade, the majority of new open source OS projects have shifted from the mobile marke...
entry.content: Over the past decade, the majority of new open source OS projects have shifted from the mobile market to the Internet of Things. In this fifth article in our IoT series, we look at the many new open source operating systems that target IoT.

entry.content: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.1 has received Red Hat’s 16th Common Criteria certification and becomes the first operating system to be certified with support for Linux container technology.

entry.summary: With the in-development Linux 4.9 kernel showing signs of some performance improvements, I've gone a...
entry.content: With the in-development Linux 4.9 kernel showing signs of some performance improvements, I've gone ahead and tested the last 21 major kernel releases on the same system. From Linux 3.9 to Linux 4.9, each of the major kernel releases was tested from the same Intel Core i7 desktop with a variety of benchmarks.

entry.title: Where to Find the World's Best Programmers
entry.summary: So which countries produce the best coders is an interesting question to ask. Perhaps more important...
entry.content: So which countries produce the best coders is an interesting question to ask. Perhaps more importantly why do some countries lead the way?

entry.title: Celebrating open standards around the world
entry.summary: Opensource.com celebrates World Standards Day on October 14. "Whether in the world of softwa...
entry.content: Opensource.com celebrates World Standards Day on October 14. "Whether in the world of software, where without standards we would have been unable to connect the world through the Internet and the World Wide Web, or the physical world, where standards make nearly everything you buy easier, more useful, and safer, the world would be a difficult place to navigate without standards. And critical to the useful of standards is making them available to all in an accessible, free format, unencumbered by legal or other hurdles."

entry.title: Human brain recalls visual features in reverse order than it detects them
entry.summary: New research has contributed to solving a paradox of perception, literally upending models of how th...
entry.content: New research has contributed to solving a paradox of perception, literally upending models of how the brain constructs interpretations of the outside world. When observing a scene, the brain first processes details -- spots, lines and simple shapes -- and uses that information to build internal representations of more complex objects, like cars and people. But during recall, the brain remembers those larger concepts first. This could shed light on concepts such as eyewitness testimony to autism.

entry.title: Novel treatment causes cancer to self-destruct without affecting healthy cells
entry.summary: Scientists have discovered the first compound that directly makes cancer cells commit suicide while ...
entry.content: Scientists have discovered the first compound that directly makes cancer cells commit suicide while sparing healthy cells. The new treatment approach, described in today’s issue of Cancer Cell, was directed against acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells but may also have potential for attacking other types of cancers.

entry.title: Molecular basis for memory and learning: Brain development and plasticity share similar signalling pathways
entry.summary: Learning and memory are two important functions of the brain that are based on the brain’s plasticit...
entry.content: Learning and memory are two important functions of the brain that are based on the brain’s plasticity. Scientists now report on how a trio of key molecules directs these processes. Their findings provide new leads for the therapy of Alzheimer’s disease.

entry.title: Watch out! Brain network calculates impact of approaching object
entry.summary: (Society for Neuroscience) A neuroimaging study of two monkeys published in JNeurosci identifies a b...
entry.content: (Society for Neuroscience) A neuroimaging study of two monkeys published in JNeurosci identifies a brain network that tracks the location of an object approaching the face and anticipates its potential consequences upon making contact with the body.

source.title: EurekAlert! - Technology, Engineering and Computer Science

entry.title: Nanoparticles that stick wounds together
entry.summary: In spite of medical advances, wound-related complications arising after operations can still be life...
entry.content: In spite of medical advances, wound-related complications arising after operations can still be life-threatening. In order to avoid these complications in the future, a new nanoparticle-based tissue glue has been developed by researchers at Empa.

source.title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

entry.title: How brain cells die in Alzheimer's and FTD
entry.summary: Removal of a regulatory gene called LSD1 in adult mice induces changes in gene activity that that lo...
entry.content: Removal of a regulatory gene called LSD1 in adult mice induces changes in gene activity that that look unexpectedly like Alzheimer's. Another surprise: LSD1 is tangled up in brain samples from humans with Alzheimer's and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), suggesting LSD1 as a central downstream player in these diseases and a drug target.

entry.content:
News
OSHA and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) have partnered with the Robotic Industries Association (RIA) to set standards for industrial robotics. Called the OSHA/NIOSH/RIA Alliance and announced on Oct. 6...
Staff Author: 
Megan Crouse
Topics: 
Robotics

entry.title: Bacteria self-organize to build working sensors
entry.summary: (Duke University) By programming bacteria with a synthetic gene circuit that can recruit gold nanopa...
entry.content: (Duke University) By programming bacteria with a synthetic gene circuit that can recruit gold nanoparticles to the surface of their colony, Duke researchers can build functional devices. A proof-of-concept study appearing in Nature Biotechnology uses this technique to build dome-shaped pressure sensors with the help of living bacteria.

entry.title: Google’s Open Source Report Card Highlights Game-Changing Contributions
entry.summary: Ask people about Google’s relationship to open source, and many of them will point to Android and Ch...
entry.content: Ask people about Google’s relationship to open source, and many of them will point to Android and Chrome OS — both very successful operating systems and both based on Linux. Android, in particular, remains one of the biggest home runs in open source history. But, as Josh Simmons from Google’s Open Source Programs Office will tell you, Google also contributes a slew of useful open source tools and programs to the community each year.

entry.title: Using encrypted documents with vim
entry.summary: Encrypting files with vim Everyone has secrets. Or at least some data you don’t want to show o...
entry.content:
Encrypting files with vim Everyone has secrets. Or at least some data you don’t want to show others, right? Vim is a common editor to be found on Linux systems. It has an option to create and use encrypted files. We will look at how to configure it and use this encryption capability. Encryption is the process of fiddling with data so that others no longer can’t read it. The idea is that you still can, so when we speak [...]

The post Using encrypted documents with vim appeared first on Linux Audit.

entry.content: Linux's power management and ACPI subsystems maintainer Rafael Wysocki presented at this week's LinuxCon Europe event in Berlin about the state and future of power management in the Linux kernel...

entry.title: Google’s Open Source Fuchsia OS: The Mystery Linux Distro
entry.summary: Few things are more tantalizing than a good mystery, and Google is making waves for an open source-c...
entry.content: Few things are more tantalizing than a good mystery, and Google is making waves for an open source-centric mystery that may end up having profound implications. It all started in August when an extensive and unusual code repository for a new operating system called Fuchsia was discovered online, and now the growing source code set is on GitHub.

entry.title: Exactly What Is OpenStack? Red Hat's Rich Bowen Explains
entry.summary: You've probably heard of OpenStack. It's in the tech news a lot, and it's an important open source p...
entry.content: You've probably heard of OpenStack. It's in the tech news a lot, and it's an important open source project. But what exactly is it, and what is it for? Rich Bowen of Red Hat provided a high-level view of OpenStack as a software project, an open source foundation, and a community of organizations in his talk at LinuxCon North America.

entry.title: 21 Open Source Projects for IoT
entry.summary: The Internet of Things market is fragmented, amorphous, and continually changing, and its very natur...
entry.content: The Internet of Things market is fragmented, amorphous, and continually changing, and its very nature requires more than the usual attention to interoperability. It’s not surprising then, that open source has done quite well here -- customers are hesitant to bet their IoT future on a proprietary platform that may fade or become difficult to customize and interconnect.

entry.title: Dig into DNS: Part 3
entry.summary: In the first and second articles in this series, I introduced the powerful dig utility and its uses ...
entry.content: In the first and second articles in this series, I introduced the powerful dig utility and its uses in performing DNS lookups along with a few time-saving examples of to put it into practice. In this part, I’ll look at my favorite dig utility feature -- which is definitely the “trace” option. For those unfamiliar with this process, let’s slowly run through it.

entry.title: Who Needs the Internet of Things?
entry.summary: This week, the Raspberry Pi Foundation announced it has sold more than 10 million Raspberry Pi board...
entry.content: This week, the Raspberry Pi Foundation announced it has sold more than 10 million Raspberry Pi boards and celebrated the milestone by releasing a new Raspberry Pi Starter Kit. While many of these Linux-driven hacker boards were used for the foundation’s original purpose -- creating a low-cost computer for computer education -- a large percentage have been sold to hobbyists and commercial developers working on Internet of Things (IoT) projects ranging from home automation to industrial sensor networks.

entry.title: ATLAS experiment studies fragments of the top quark
entry.summary: Top quarks in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) proton-proton collisions are predominantly produced in...
entry.content: Top quarks in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) proton-proton collisions are predominantly produced in pairs, with one top quark and one top antiquark. In order to measure the production rates of top quark pairs, the ATLAS Experiment examined events with an electron, muon, and one or two jets that were likely to have originated from bottom quarks. By comparing the number of events with one bottom-quark jet to those with two bottom-quark jets, ATLAS was able to determine both the total production rate, as well as the efficiency of identifying bottom-flavoured jets.

source.title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

entry.title: Japan scientists grow drugs in chicken eggs
entry.summary: Japanese researchers have genetically engineered hens whose eggs contain drugs that can fight seriou...
entry.content: Japanese researchers have genetically engineered hens whose eggs contain drugs that can fight serious diseases including cancer, in a bid to dramatically reduce the cost of treatment, a report said Monday.

source.title: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

entry.title: Plant cells survive but stop dividing upon DNA damage
entry.summary: The cell cycle is how a cell passes its DNA but ceases if the DNA is damaged, as otherwise it risks ...
entry.content: The cell cycle is how a cell passes its DNA but ceases if the DNA is damaged, as otherwise it risks passing this damage to daughter cells. Scientists report a new molecular mechanism that explains how this cessation occurs. The study shows that the transcription factor family MYB3R is normally degraded, but accumulates upon DNA damage to prevent cell cycle progression.

entry.title: How Google Uses and Contributes to Open Source
entry.summary: Engineer Marc Merlin has been working at Google since 2001 but has been involved with Linux since 19...
entry.content: Engineer Marc Merlin has been working at Google since 2001 but has been involved with Linux since 1993, in its very early days. Since then, open source adoption has dramatically increased, but a new challenge is emerging: Not many companies care about the license side of open source, Merlin stated in his talk “How Google Uses and Contributes to Open Source” at LinuxCon and ContainerCon North America.

entry.title: IBM Launches New Linux, Power8, OpenPower Systems
entry.summary: IBM on Thursday rolled out its latest Power8 processor, which is designed to move data faster, and n...
entry.content:
IBM on Thursday rolled out its latest Power8 processor, which is designed to move data faster, and new servers with OpenPower features. For IBM, the OpenPower Foundation community is critical for its Power8 processor. A bevy of companies are in OpenPower, a group that aims to be a counterweight to x86-based servers. 

With the new systems, IBM is hoping to target more artificial intelligence, analytics, and deep learning workloads. 

Read more at ZDNet

entry.title: Machine Learning: The Bigger Picture, Part I
entry.summary: In the past few decades, computer systems have achieved a whole lot. They have managed to organize a...
entry.content: In the past few decades, computer systems have achieved a whole lot. They have managed to organize and catalog the information produced by our civilization as a whole. They have relieved us from stringent cognitive tasks and increased our productivity significantly. One could say that where the industrial revolution automated labor, the digital revolution has automated cognitive labor. This statement isn’t entirely correct however, if it was we would all be without a job. So what can humans do that machines can’t?
